topic: Property Valuation and Financial Analysis
question_text: Which of the following best describes the state of the market during the expansion phase of the real estate cycle?
A: High but stabilized unemployment and a high number of foreclosures
B: Increases in hiring, employment, and public confidence, and lots of buyers in the market
C: Properties selling at inflated prices, many buyers in the market, and lots of new construction
D: Unemployment increasing, prices falling, and foreclosures on the rise
explanation: Expansion is when activity starts to really pick up. Companies are hiring, so unemployment decreases. Higher employment means more buyers in the market and more overall public confidence.

topic: Practice of Real Estate and Disclosures, Including Specialty Areas
question_text: Transactions involving which of the following properties require a Real Estate Transfer Disclosure Statement?
explanation: Residential home sales of dwellings of one to four units, including manufactured homes, require disclosures using the TDS.

topic: Practice of Real Estate and Disclosures, Including Specialty Areas
subtopic: Licensing and Continuing Education Requirements and Procedures
question_text: Sally is a real estate salesperson. How many hours of continuing education must she complete before the license expiration date in order to renew it for another four years?
explanation: Real estate brokers and salespersons must complete 45 hours of continuing education during the four years immediately preceding their license expiration date.

topic: Property Ownership and Land Use Controls and Regulations
question_text: Tres owns a warehouse in an area that is zoned light industrial. With an increased demand for housing in the area, Tres wants to create loft-style condos and have his property designated as residential, even though the surrounding buildings will remain light industrial. What type of zoning is this?
explanation: Spot zoning allows a specific property to be rezoned within an existing zoning area. Spot zoning is illegal in some states.

topic: Practice of Real Estate and Disclosures, Including Specialty Areas
subtopic: Licensing and Continuing Education Requirements and Procedures
question_text: Jimbo doesn't yet have a real estate license. Which activity is he legally allowed to perform without one?
A: Give advice to a friend who is negotiating the purchase of a house.
B: List a friend or family member's home for sale for a fee.
C: Negotiate the sale of a house for two friends and receive a tip in thanks.
D: Receive payment for managing real estate.
explanation: Any activity performed for another and for a fee requires a license. Jimbo should be in the clear if he gives advice to his friend negotiating the purchase of a house as long as he's not compensated for it.

topic: Property Ownership and Land Use Controls and Regulations
question_text: What act requires sellers, landlords, and their agents to disclose any known lead hazards in the home?
C: Residential Lead-Based Paint Hazard Reduction Act
explanation: The Residential Lead-Based Paint Hazard Reduction Act requires this disclosure. It also requires them to provide a lead safety pamphlet and any records they have of lead assessments or testing to prospective buyers.

topic: Practice of Real Estate and Disclosures, Including Specialty Areas
subtopic: Licensing and Continuing Education Requirements and Procedures
question_text: June has worked with buyers and sellers for years. When homeowners default on their mortgage, June acts as trustee for the deed of trust. Under the deed of trust, June has the authority to sell the property. Does June have a real estate license?
A: If she receives compensation for performing this activity, she must have a real estate license.
B: No, trustees selling properties under a deed of trust are exempt from licensure.
C: She only needs a real estate license if she is selling her own property.
D: Yes, she is selling property for others. She must have a real estate license.
explanation: Certain individuals are exempt from obtaining a real estate license to perform real estate activities. Trustees selling properties under a deed of trust are exempt from licensure.

topic: Practice of Real Estate and Disclosures, Including Specialty Areas
question_text: A brokerage offers flat fee, menu-based services. Two other firms decide to not show any of the brokerage's listings and to prohibit showings from its buyers to drive it out of business. What is this an example of?
explanation: This is group boycotting because it involves a group of licensees agreeing not to do business with another group.

topic: Property Valuation and Financial Analysis
question_text: Which economic principle is in play when the smallest property's value increases because it's surrounded by higher-value properties?
explanation: Progression is the bump in value that a lower-value property gets by being near a higher-value property.

topic: Property Ownership and Land Use Controls and Regulations
question_text: A developer has a subdivision of 140 houses. The developer can place deed restrictions on as many as ______ properties.
explanation: Deed restrictions can be placed on an individual property, an entire subdivision, or a neighborhood.

topic: Property Ownership and Land Use Controls and Regulations
question_text: A tax ____ is a legal claim to property as a means of satisfying a delinquent property tax debt.
explanation: A tax lien is a legal claim to property as a means of satisfying a delinquent property tax debt.

topic: Practice of Real Estate and Disclosures, Including Specialty Areas
subtopic: Licensing and Continuing Education Requirements and Procedures
question_text: Al is 70 years old and has held his real estate broker license in good standing for 30 consecutive years. His license is up for renewal soon. How many continuing education hours must he complete?
explanation: Licensees who are at least 70 years old and who are licensed in good standing for at least 30 consecutive years are exempt from the continuing education requirements. They must still submit a renewal application and pay a fee, but they are exempt from CE.

topic: Financing
question_text: A homeowner has applied for a home equity line of credit from his federally insured bank so that he can make some renovations to his kitchen. The same bank is his lender for his home mortgage. Will this loan be subject to Real Estate Settlement Procedures Act requirements?
A: No, because the homeowner won't be using a real estate professional.
B: No, because there's no transfer of title involved.
C: Yes, because RESPA applies to any residential loan transaction from a federally insured financial institution, including equity lines of credit.
D: Yes, because the bank is also the lender for his home mortgage. If he'd used a different lender, RESPA would not apply.
explanation: RESPA regulations apply to loans on one- to four-family residential properties, including assumptions, refinances, home improvement loans, and equity lines of credit.

topic: Transfer of Property
question_text: Kandy was so excited to be buying her first home, a condo in a San Diego beach neighborhood. Thanks to an inheritance, she was able to pay for the property in cash! She gazed adoringly at her deed, admiring each of its elements that proclaimed her the sole owner of 1256 Voltaire Street, Unit 15. Which of these is NOT on Kandy's deed?
C: Names of the grantor and the grantee
explanation: Only the grantor is required to sign a deed to make it valid. Kandy is the grantee. The grantor's signature must be acknowledged in order for the deed to be properly recorded with the county.

topic: Transfer of Property
question_text: Your seller client has accepted an offer on his home, and you're on your way to closing. Which of these is NOT a tax aspect that you'll explain to your client (in basic terms) related to the transfer of property?
A: "If you make a profit on the sale of this property, you'll have to pay a capital gains tax when you file your income taxes."
B: "Property taxes are prorated so you'll only pay for the time you owned the property."
C: "When you're buying your next home, the transfer will trigger a reassessment for property tax purposes."
D: "Your title will reveal any tax liens, so the title company will review it to ensure that isn't an encumbrance."
explanation: The seller isn't always going to owe capital gains on a profit from the sale of a home, since the IRS allows an exclusion for an individual of $250,000 of gain.

topic: Property Ownership and Land Use Controls and Regulations
question_text: A county courthouse is exempt from property taxes because it is ______-owned.
explanation: If a property is government-owned, it is exempt from property taxes.

topic: Financing
question_text: Which of these items did the Federal Housing Administration (FHA) implement to stabilize and improve the mortgage market?
A: Educate the public about the benefits and responsibilities of having a mortgage
C: Set construction standards for homes purchased with FHA loans
D: Set standards for interest rates on mortgage loans
explanation: The FHA requires specific construction standards for buildings purchased with an FHA loan, which reduces lender and insurer risk.

topic: Practice of Real Estate and Disclosures, Including Specialty Areas
subtopic: Licensing and Continuing Education Requirements and Procedures
question_text: Bradley has a real estate salesperson's license. He's done some traveling recently and missed the deadline to renew his license. It's now 30 days past the expiration date. What must he do to renew his license?
A: Complete the continuing education requirements and submit a renewal and late fee.
B: File an appeal with the Real estate Commissioner.
C: Re-qualify for a real estate license by completing pre-licensing courses and passing the state licensing exam.
explanation: Licenses expired less than two years follow the traditional renewal process, but Bradley will pay a late fee in addition to the renewal fee.

topic: Financing
question_text: An individual is purchasing a small craft shop, including the underlying real estate. She applies for a commercial loan from her federally insured bank to complete the purchase. Is this transaction covered by the Real Estate Settlement Procedures Act?
A: No. Commercial and business loans are exempt from RESPA requirements.
B: No. RESPA only applies to loans obtained from private lenders.
C: Yes. All loans secured by real estate are subject to RESPA requirements.
D: Yes. Because the loan is from a federally insured financial institution, the loan is subject to RESPA requirements.
explanation: Commercial and business loans are exempt from RESPA.

topic: Practice of Real Estate and Disclosures, Including Specialty Areas
question_text: Karla is a sponsoring broker who owns her own brokerage. She has two associate brokers and two salespersons, who all work as independent contractors. She also has an unlicensed assistant on payroll as an employee. Which of the following is true of Karla's liability?
A: Karla is liable for the actions of all members of her firm, both the independent contractors and the employee.
B: Karla is only liable for the actions of her associate brokers.
C: Karla is only liable for the actions of her associate brokers and salespersons.
D: Karla is only liable for the actions of her salespersons.
explanation: Sponsoring brokers are liable for the activities of the members of their firm. This is true whether the members are independent contractors, such as salespeople and associate brokers, or employees.

topic: Practice of Real Estate and Disclosures, Including Specialty Areas
question_text: You've been in real estate for a while, have your broker's license, and have been serving as an associate broker for several years. If you have business acumen and like managing people, a natural next step in your career would be becoming a _______.
explanation: A real estate broker supervises real estate licensees and owns a real estate firm.

topic: Financing
question_text: Maura is a real estate salesperson who does not have an MLO endorsement. Which of these actions can she perform for her client, who is financing the purchase of a single-family home?
A: Offer to negotiate the terms of the client's loan application.
B: Offer to provide the client with a list of lenders they could consider working with to obtain the loan.
D: Take the client's residential mortgage loan application.
explanation: Taking a residential loan application, negotiating the terms of the loan, servicing the loan, or offering to do any of these activities for the client requires an MLO endorsement. Maura can provide her client with a list of lenders to consider.

topic: Financing
question_text: Borrowers obtaining a VA loan aren't required to have a down payment. However, they are required to pay _______.
explanation: First-time homebuyers pay a funding fee of 2.15% (2.4% for those in the reserves or National Guard) if they don't have a down payment. This funding fee increases to 3.3% for second-time buyers.

topic: Practice of Real Estate and Disclosures, Including Specialty Areas
question_text: What is the illegal practice of nudging buyers away from or toward a specific area based on the presence or absence of protected class members?
explanation: Using an area's demographic make-up in order to steer protected classes away from or to specific neighborhoods is steering, and it's illegal.

topic: Transfer of Property
question_text: What might an individual's mother have bequeathed to them?
A: Their interest in an oil drilling operation
explanation: A bequest or legacy is a gift of personal property. In this case, the individual is the legatee (recipient).

topic: Financing
question_text: In relation to the work of an MLO, which of the following is an example of a residential mortgage loan?
A: A home equity line of credit
B: A loan taken by a developer to build a home
C: A loan taken to purchase a business
D: A loan taken to purchase an office building
explanation: According to rules regulating mortgage loan originators, loans to purchase a residential property, refinance an existing residential real property loan, or a home equity line of credit are considered residential mortgage loans.

topic: Practice of Real Estate and Disclosures, Including Specialty Areas
subtopic: Licensing and Continuing Education Requirements and Procedures
question_text: Which activity can you perform without a license in California?
A: Negotiate rent for another tenant in the office building where you work.
B: Negotiate rent of an office building for the nonprofit where you work.
C: Negotiate the sale price of a friend's office building for a fee.
D: Sell your neighbor's house for a fee.
explanation: Negotiating a lease on behalf of your employer as tenant does not require a license.

topic: Financing
question_text: If a buyer puts the minimum 3.5% down on a $210,000 home and pays a MIP, what type of loan do they have?
explanation: Based on the minimum down payment amount of 3.5% and the fact that they're paying MIP, the buyer has an FHA loan.

topic: Property Ownership and Land Use Controls and Regulations
question_text: Which of these is the best definition of real estate?
B: Land, plus all things permanently attached to it naturally or artificially
C: Real property, plus all of the interests, benefits, and rights included in ownership
D: The earth's surface extending downward to the center of the earth and upward to infinity, including permanently attached natural objects
explanation: Real estate includes land, plus all things permanently attached to it naturally or artificially.

topic: Transfer of Property
question_text: Siblings Julia and Gene are co-owners of a small retail building in which a tanning salon is currently operating. Gene really wants to leave his ownership interest to his son when he dies, but the way in which they own the property doesn't allow him to do so. What type of ownership do they have?
explanation: Joint tenancy does not include the right of inheritance; ownership interest passes to the remaining tenants once a tenant dies.

topic: Practice of Real Estate and Disclosures, Including Specialty Areas
question_text: Which of the following is one of the primary reasons that developers like to invest in unimproved land?
A: It looks good to top investors to have a portfolio of unimproved land.
B: It's easier to build on a blank canvas than it is to retrofit existing infrastructure.
D: Structures are already erected on the land, limiting the development that needs to be done.
explanation: Developers continue to buy unimproved land because it's easier to start with a blank canvas than it is to demolish and remove existing structures. Also, retrofitting can be costly and time consuming.

topic: Financing
question_text: What are the main benefits to veterans of the VA-guaranteed loan program?
A: A VA guarantee of the property condition
B: Lower interest rates than are available on the open market
C: No down payment, no mortgage insurance, and no prepayment penalty
explanation: Veterans benefit because the VA requires no down payment, no mortgage insurance, and doesn't have a prepayment penalty.

topic: Financing
question_text: What attracts borrowers to adjustable rate mortgages?
explanation: Some consumers are attracted to ARMs because of their lower interest rate for an initial period of one to several years.

topic: Property Ownership and Land Use Controls and Regulations
question_text: Jacqueline is a licensee working with a property near a Superfund site. Which of these statements is true?
A: A portion of the sale price must go to the EPA to fund clean-up of the site.
B: She must disclose potential health threats to anyone in the area when showing the property.
C: She must disclose the existence of an environmental hazard in the area.
D: The property can't be sold until the site is removed from the NPL.
explanation: A property with a known Superfund site in the vicinity requires disclosure, as this is a material fact.

topic: Practice of Real Estate and Disclosures, Including Specialty Areas
question_text: Which of the following is true of agreeing with a competitor to segment the market between you?
A: It's an example of a tie-in arrangement and an antitrust violation.
B: It's an example of group boycotting and an antitrust violation.
C: It's an example of market allocation and an antitrust violation.
explanation: This action reduces choices for consumers and reduces competition. This is illegal market allocation.

topic: Transfer of Property
question_text: In a typical transaction, which of these title defects is unlikely to cause a problem for the buyer?
C: A past error in recording title transfer
explanation: Most property transactions include an existing mortgage that creates a title defect, but the defect will be cleared at closing when the seller's proceeds are used to pay off the loan.

topic: Practice of Real Estate and Disclosures, Including Specialty Areas
question_text: Which of the following professional certifications for property managers applies to an individual?
explanation: A Certified Property Manager (CPM) means that the individual has the education and experience required by the professional organization IREM.

topic: Property Ownership and Land Use Controls and Regulations
question_text: Which of the following individuals is exempt from contractor licensing requirements?
A: Diedre, who is remodeling her kitchen because extended family is coming to live with her
B: May, who is updating her bathroom to prepare her house for market
C: Ray, who is replacing his neighbor's garage door for $550
D: Thomas, who is putting in a covered porch for Susan at a cost of $1,250
explanation: Homeowners are exempt only if they are doing the work without the intent to sell. Work that will cost more than $500 requires a license.

topic: Contracts
question_text: Which of these sentences accurately describes the phrase "statute of limitations"?
A: There are deadlines for certain types of legal action.
B: There are limits to how many times someone may sue another person.
C: There are limits to the monetary damages that may be awarded in a civil suit.
D: There's a limit to the number of statutes that may be enacted each year.
explanation: The statute of limitations provides that, for certain breaches or crimes, the aggrieved party must file a complaint or charges within a specific timeframe. The deadline varies by state and wrongdoing.

topic: Financing
question_text: What could be a consequence if there were no secondary mortgage market?
B: Lenders might not have funds available to make new loans to the public.
C: There wouldn't be any institutions available to service loans.
explanation: Purchases made on the secondary market provide primary lenders with funds to continue making loans. Without this market, lending funds might become scarce.

topic: Property Ownership and Land Use Controls and Regulations
question_text: San Diego homeowner Carl hasn't paid his property taxes for three years in a row. The county has a tax lien attached to his property. Can the county foreclose on Carl?
A: No, a property tax lien doesn't give the lien holder the power of sale.
B: No, California law prohibits foreclosure for a tax lien.
C: Yes, but only if his taxes remain unpaid for five years.
explanation: The county can foreclose on Carl, but not until his taxes have been unpaid for five years.

topic: Financing
question_text: Mary is a licensed real estate professional. She only performs licensed real estate activities and does not receive any compensation from lenders, mortgage brokers, or other mortgage-related parties. Does she need an MLO endorsement?
A: No, real estate licensees are not eligible to obtain an MLO endorsement.
B: No, she does not need an MLO endorsement if she only performs real estate activities and does not receive compensation from mortgage-related parties.
C: Yes, all licensed real estate professionals must hold an MLO endorsement.
D: Yes, she must have an MLO if she intends to work with buyers.
explanation: A person doesn't need an MLO endorsement if they only perform licensed real estate activities and DO NOT receive any compensation from lenders, mortgage brokers, MLOs, or any agents of these parties.

topic: Practice of Real Estate and Disclosures, Including Specialty Areas
question_text: Gregory has been bombarded with emails from a local real estate licensee. He keeps opting out of these emails, but they just keep coming. What federal law is the licensee possibly violating?
explanation: The CAN-SPAM Act of 2003 protects consumers against unwanted email solicitations.

topic: Property Ownership and Land Use Controls and Regulations
question_text: Travis is a new real estate licensee and is writing up his first offer to purchase for his buyer clients. Which of these statements is true?
A: Real estate licensees don't have access to legal descriptions.
B: Travis should include the legal description in the offer, because it provides a complete description of the property.
C: Travis should not include the legal description on the offer to purchase, but he should include the address.
D: Travis shouldn't write up the offer to purchase; the client should.
explanation: Travis should (and must) include the legal description. Legal descriptions appear in deeds, mortgages, leases, offers to purchase, tax rolls, county records, and title insurance policies.

topic: Laws of Agency and Fiduciary Duties
subtopic: Law, Definition and Nature of Agency Relationships, Types of Agencies, and Agents
question_text: Terry represents seller Farrah, and Michael represents Troy, the buyer. Who is (or are) the principal(s) in this transaction?
explanation: Farrah and Troy are the principals (parties) to the transaction. Farrah is the principal in her agency relationship with Terry, and Troy with Michael.

topic: Practice of Real Estate and Disclosures, Including Specialty Areas
question_text: Your buyer client is preparing an offer on a property. They want to make sure their offer stands out above all others and is accepted, so they discuss waiving the inspection contingency with you. What should you do?
A: Encourage the buyer to get an inspection, and if they still want to waive it, put it in writing that you advised against waiving the inspection and have them sign.
B: Follow the buyer's wishes without question.
C: Ignore the buyer's request to waive the inspection.
explanation: Always recommend buyers get an inspection. This is part of their due diligence, and advocating for it is part of yours. If a buyer wants to waive the inspection, get their waiver in writing.

topic: Property Ownership and Land Use Controls and Regulations
question_text: April was able to establish a day care in a residential neighborhood, where the zoning wouldn't normally be permitted. This required permission from the planning board and ______.
explanation: A variance is a permitted deviation; a special use permit is a specially permitted use.

topic: Practice of Real Estate and Disclosures, Including Specialty Areas
question_text: A landlord refuses to rent an apartment to two single men who live together. However, the landlord has also approved a lease application from two unmarried women who cohabit. The landlord is discriminating on the basis of what federally protected class?
explanation: Refusing to rent an apartment to two single men living together, but granting a lease to two single women who do the same thing, is sex discrimination. Familial status refers to the presence of children under 18, and it's worth noting that we don't know what their relationship is-just like the landlord doesn't!

topic: Financing
question_text: A buyer using a VA loan has received a CRV valuation at less than the sale price of the home. If the seller refuses to come down in price, the buyer can ______.
A: Ask the VA for an increase in her entitlement
C: Obtain a second loan to make up the difference between CRV and sales price
D: Pay the difference between the CRV and sales price in cash
explanation: When the CRV is less than the sales price, the buyer can pay the difference between the CRV and the sales price in cash in order to get the VA loan.

topic: Financing
question_text: Which of these names is also known as the California Real Property Loan Law?
explanation: The California Real Property Loan Law is also known as the Mortgage Loan Broker Law, the Necessitous Borrower Act, and Article VII of the Real Estate Law

topic: Property Valuation and Financial Analysis
question_text: Population growth, marriage rates, and attitudes toward education are examples of which force that influences property value?
explanation: These are examples of social forces that influence value. Other examples of social forces include divorce rates and ideals about family size.

topic: Practice of Real Estate and Disclosures, Including Specialty Areas
subtopic: Disclosure of Material Facts Affecting Property Value
question_text: Stacy is selling her home in a nice neighborhood. She no longer wants to live there because a gruesome murder occurred next door. Would Stacy need to disclose that this is why she is selling?
A: No, but she should disclose that the neighbors were the victims of a violent crime.
B: No, she is not required to disclose a death that didn't occur on her property.
C: Yes, murder must always be disclosed, even if it's not on the property itself.
D: Yes, the murder next door stigmatizes her property and she must disclose.
explanation: Because the murder did not occur on Stacy's property, the property isn't stigmatized. Stacy's reasons for moving are confidential.

topic: Property Ownership and Land Use Controls and Regulations
question_text: What is true regarding trade fixtures affixed to walls that may cause damage to the property upon removal?
A: The renter has three months to remove them after the lease expires.
B: The renter is required to leave the fixtures if they're attached.
C: The renter is required to take the fixtures and return the premises to its original condition.
D: The renter may take the fixtures as long as they repair any damage caused by removal.
explanation: Commercial tenants may remove trade fixtures when the lease ends, but only if they are detachable without damaging the property or if the damage is repaired.

topic: Practice of Real Estate and Disclosures, Including Specialty Areas
subtopic: Need for Inspection and Obtaining/Verfiying Information
question_text: Donald and Martina decided to purchase a newly built home, and their agent, Ed, recommended that they get a professional home inspection done. The couple tells Ed that they thought inspections were only for older homes. How should Ed respond to that?
A: Ed needs to inform his clients that home inspections are most important for newer properties.
B: Ed should let them know that lenders for new construction loans require inspections.
C: Ed should remind them that every dwelling, no matter the age or size, should have a home inspection.
D: Ed should tell him that he doesn't trust the builder.
explanation: Workmanship issues can be found even in new construction, so licensees should always recommend a home inspection.

topic: Practice of Real Estate and Disclosures, Including Specialty Areas
subtopic: Disclosure of Material Facts Affecting Property Value
question_text: After closing, a buyer discovers the seller wasn't honest about the property condition on the state's required disclosures. What can the buyer do?
A: Ask for a refund of his earnest money.
B: Sue the seller for fraud or breach of contract.
D: The buyer has no options after closing.
explanation: Once closing occurs, the contract is complete. There's no longer an option to terminate it or ask for earnest money back. However, the buyer can sue the seller for fraud or breach of contract.

topic: Contracts
question_text: Carter, a licensee, never posts his clients' property on the MLS. This gives him the opportunity to find the buyer himself, potentially doubling his commission. What disadvantage might apply to Carter's clients?
B: Their properties may not sell for top dollar.
C: They may receive too many offers if Carters' network is too wide.
D: They will pay more commission overall.
explanation: It's important that the listing agent ensures the client's understanding of the benefits of using the MLS, which include increased exposure. Opting out could have a negative impact on the sales price.

topic: Practice of Real Estate and Disclosures, Including Specialty Areas
question_text: Your broker has received an earnest money check from you for a transaction. Where should this check be deposited?
B: In a trust fund account or neutral escrow
C: In the firm's general business account, with a ledger entry for the client's name, labeled "trust fund"
D: In the firm's safe or safety deposit box until closing
explanation: Trust funds must be held in accounts separate from personal and business funds to be in compliance with commissioner's regulations and the Business and Professions Code.

topic: Contracts
question_text: Shirley's lender discharged the mortgage lien on Shirley's property after processing her final payment. Which clause requires the lender to take this action?
explanation: The defeasance clause means the lender may not pursue the borrower for additional funds when the loan balance is paid in full.

topic: Practice of Real Estate and Disclosures, Including Specialty Areas
question_text: A licensee decides to stop doing business with a local mortgage company that is charging clients hefty fees. The licensee convinces the buyer brokers who show her listing to follow suit. What is this an example of?
explanation: This is group boycotting because it involves a group of licensees agreeing to not do business with another group.

topic: Practice of Real Estate and Disclosures, Including Specialty Areas
subtopic: Disclosure of Material Facts Affecting Property Value
question_text: What California case helped define the level of responsibility that real estate professionals and sellers have when it comes to disclosure of material facts?
C: Eaton v. California Bureau of Real Estate
explanation: The 1984 case of Easton v. Strassburger resulted in a court decision that helped define the responsibility of a real estate agent to conduct a visual inspection, and of a seller to disclose all known material facts.

topic: Property Ownership and Land Use Controls and Regulations
question_text: Homeowners Daryl and Stella, who are both in their 70s, paid off their mortgage during good times, but recent medical bills have overcome them and their creditors have a judgment lien against their property. They decide to sell their home and downsize to pay off their bills. Which of these is NOT true about the homestead exemption for them?
A: The declaration of homestead will protect a portion of their equity.
B: The holder of the judgment lien will be paid before they receive their exemption.
C: They'll need to purchase another home within six months of the sale.
D: They must first file a declaration of homestead.
explanation: The homestead exemption in California protects a portion of this couple's equity as long as they've filed a declaration of homestead and invest the proceeds within six months. The judgment lien is paid AFTER the exemption.

topic: Practice of Real Estate and Disclosures, Including Specialty Areas
question_text: Why did the Civil Rights Act of 1866 fail to have an immediate impact on practice?
B: Nobody understood the Civil Rights Act.
C: The protected classes had to be approved.
D: There was no agency put in place to enforce the laws.
explanation: There was no agency put in place to enforce the Civil Rights Act of 1866. It would take another 100 years for real change to occur.

topic: Practice of Real Estate and Disclosures, Including Specialty Areas
question_text: The California DRE is performing a routine audit of Gold Standard Brokerage, Inc. Broker Chip is sweating bullets since he knows they're likely to find some of his creative accounting involving the brokerage trust fund. Why is Chip nervous?
A: He is afraid the DRE will think he's been embezzling funds, when he's only been moving the funds to get the most bang for his clients' bucks.
B: He knows he'll have to fire most of his associated licensees in order to hide his own activities from the DRE audit.
C: He needs to put back some funds he borrowed from the trust account before the DRE sees that they're missing.
D: He's likely to face serious disciplinary action when the audit uncovers his inappropriate handling of trust funds.
explanation: There's no hiding inappropriate trust fund handling from a DRE audit. Chip is very likely to face disciplinary action when the audit uncovers his shenanigans.

topic: Practice of Real Estate and Disclosures, Including Specialty Areas
question_text: James represented a client who believes James was guilty of misrepresentation. The client files a complaint against James. Which entity will investigate?
explanation: California DRE investigates complaints related to license law violations filed against California real estate licensees.

topic: Property Valuation and Financial Analysis
question_text: Margot has fallen in love with a three-bedroom, 2,500-square-foot property in her friend's neighborhood. It's listed for $400,000. However, just down the street, another three-bedroom, 2,400- square-foot home very similar to the one Margot loves was just listed for $350,000. Margot and her agent immediately make an offer on the second property. Which economic principle is at work here?
explanation: Margot knows paying $50,000 more for a nearly identical substitute property isn't the smart choice.

topic: Property Ownership and Land Use Controls and Regulations
question_text: In addition to providing a disclosure of any lead-based paint hazards in homes built before 1978, what must a seller's agent provide to prospective buyers?
A: Assurance that the home is lead-free before offering it for sale
C: List of reputable home improvement contractors
D: Written proof that the home is lead-free
explanation: The seller's agent must also provide knowledge of whether lead paint has been found and mitigated to prospective buyers.

topic: Laws of Agency and Fiduciary Duties
question_text: Before entering into an agency relationship with a consumer, what must a licensee do?
D: Provide an agency disclosure form and obtain signatures
explanation: Agency disclosure forms must be provided as soon as practicable, and before entering into an agency relationship.

topic: Practice of Real Estate and Disclosures, Including Specialty Areas
question_text: Inga recently came into some money and is thinking of getting into real estate investments, but she doesn't have a lot of experience with either real estate or investment strategies. Which of these properties would be her best bet?
A: A 100-unit apartment complex near where she lives
C: An office building downtown with space for three tenants
D: Single-family residential as a rental property
explanation: Residential income property like the single-family home used as a rental will be the easiest for Inga to understand and to purchase. She can work her way up to more complicated commercial properties later, or she can specialize in residential.

topic: Practice of Real Estate and Disclosures, Including Specialty Areas
question_text: Which of the following is true of developing a market niche based on any legal category (e.g., farming or prospecting a specific area)?
A: It's an example of a tie-in arrangement and is an antitrust violation.
B: It's an example of group boycotting and is an antitrust violation.
C: It's an example of market allocation and is an antitrust violation.
explanation: Licensees and even brokerages may develop a market niche to serve in the industry.

topic: Laws of Agency and Fiduciary Duties
question_text: Under which of the following circumstances would the client and agent most likely mutually agree to terminate a listing?
A: A buyer approached the seller with a much higher offer than the current listing price.
B: The agent and client don't agree on the best way to price, maintain, and market the property.
C: The client has found a buyer and wants to avoid paying a commission.
D: The client's cousin just became licensed and needs her first listing.
explanation: When an agent and seller client can't agree on important aspects of selling the property, the relationship will not benefit anyone. Mutual termination is a valid way to terminate the agency agreement.

topic: Property Ownership and Land Use Controls and Regulations
question_text: What type of police power allows cities to identify specific uses for an area?
explanation: Zoning dictates how an area can be used, and should follow the area's general or comprehensive plan.

topic: Contracts
question_text: Which of the following situations entitles Gary to commission with a 30-day protection clause?
A: Buyers viewed the property 15 days after the listing expired and made an offer that was accepted.
B: Buyers who viewed the property while it was listed with Gary made an accepted offer 10 days after the listing expired.
C: Gary told his overseas cousin about the property, and his cousin returned to the U.S. 35 days after the listing expired to make an offer.
D: The seller told a group of colleagues about the house 20 days after the listing expired, and one eventually came to see the house, which led to a contract.
explanation: The contract must be signed within the protection period and be the result of the broker's actions during the initial listing period.

topic: Practice of Real Estate and Disclosures, Including Specialty Areas
subtopic: Disclosure of Material Facts Affecting Property Value
question_text: Water buildup, ice damming, and a fascia damaged by moisture are common ______ issues.
explanation: Water buildup and ice damming can occur in gutters, and severe weather can damage fascia. Buyers need to know about issues with the roof prior to buying a property.

topic: Property Ownership and Land Use Controls and Regulations
question_text: Many parks and golf courses are the sites of ______.
explanation: Many parks and golf courses are the site of former landfills.

topic: Contracts
question_text: Generally, there are covenants between the borrower and the lender within a mortgage document. Which of the following is a mortgage covenant?
A: Agree to refinance only with the current lender.
B: Give the lender first right of refusal.
C: Move all checking and savings account to the lender's institution.
D: Pay any charges and assessments against the property.
explanation: Covenants usually include paying charges and assessments against the property, maintaining both the property and hazard insurance, and keeping the property in good condition.

topic: Property Ownership and Land Use Controls and Regulations
question_text: According to national standards for measuring square footage of a dwelling, which space should be included?
explanation: Garages and unfinished spaces may be included as unfinished square footage only.

topic: Property Ownership and Land Use Controls and Regulations
question_text: Rancher Ross was thrilled to learn he could sell his property's mineral rights to a company that's looking for oil. He didn't realize he'd also created an ______, allowing them to bring drilling equipment onto his land.
explanation: An easement by implication is created by the parties' conduct. A mineral right is worthless unless the minerals can be accessed, so selling the right implies that Ross granted the oil company permission to bring drilling equipment onto his land.

topic: Transfer of Property
question_text: Which term is defined as the build-up of land near water from the accumulation of sand, silt, or gravel deposits?
explanation: Accretion is the term used to describe the build-up of land near water from the accumulation of sand, silt, or gravel deposits.

topic: Property Valuation and Financial Analysis
question_text: Which of these properties are exempt from the FIRREA federal appraisal guidelines?
explanation: Properties valued at $400,000 or less are exempt from federal appraisal requirements in federally related transactions .

topic: Practice of Real Estate and Disclosures, Including Specialty Areas
question_text: What's true about the Natural Hazard Disclosure statement?
A: Buyers must receive the NHD within seven days after offer acceptance, but it can be provided to prospective buyers at the first opportunity.
B: It's not required unless the buyer requests it.
C: It's required only if the property is located in one of six natural hazard zones.
D: Sellers must provide the NHD to the buyer at least three days before closing unless the buyer waives the right to the disclosure.
explanation: The NHD should be provided to prospective buyers at the first opportunity. The Residential Purchase Agreement requires the disclosures be provided to the buyer within seven days after offer acceptance.

topic: Practice of Real Estate and Disclosures, Including Specialty Areas
question_text: The U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development cites discrimination and ______ as two barriers to a stronger level of minority homeownership.
B: An insufficient supply of affordable housing
C: Lack of interest in owning a home
explanation: HUD's research indicates that an insufficient supply of affordable housing disproportionately affects minority homebuyers.

topic: Laws of Agency and Fiduciary Duties
question_text: For how long must a licensee retain a signed agency disclosure?
B: For one year after the agency relationship ends
explanation: Signed agency disclosures must be retained for three years.

topic: Property Ownership and Land Use Controls and Regulations
question_text: Which one of the following actions is a recommended (and in some states, required) method for protecting occupants of a home from carbon monoxide poisoning?
A: Have a licensed professional install a vent system if carbon monoxide levels are unacceptable.
C: Remove all gas-powered devices from the home.
D: Replace all gas-powered appliances with newer electric models.
explanation: A carbon monoxide alarm is an inexpensive and easy safeguard to install. Many states require all residential properties have such devices.

topic: Property Ownership and Land Use Controls and Regulations
question_text: Without this easement-usually involving access to a road-the owner requiring the right of passage would be landlocked.
explanation: This describes an easement by necessity. One way to remember this type of easement is by thinking of the importance of getting access to a road.

topic: Property Ownership and Land Use Controls and Regulations
question_text: In California, which lien can be filed later than other liens and still have priority over them?
explanation: In California, a mechanic's lien can take priority over other liens if the starting date of the project was before the other liens' filing dates.

topic: Property Ownership and Land Use Controls and Regulations
question_text: A buyer is interested in purchasing a piece of property, but before doing so, they'd like to verify the accuracy of the legal description. Which of these options will accomplish this?
D: Looking up the property on Google Earth
explanation: A survey is a professional, on-site measurement of the lot lines and dimensions of a property, including the location of any improvements, encroachments, and easements of public record.

topic: Practice of Real Estate and Disclosures, Including Specialty Areas
subtopic: Need for Inspection and Obtaining/Verfiying Information
question_text: What is the primary goal of a home inspector completing a home inspection for first-time buyers?
A: Document health and safety issues that may affect both the cost and enjoyment of the home.
B: Estimate how much cosmetic upgrades may cost the buyers.
C: Verify lot lines and acreage calculations.
D: Verify the presence of any easements or encroachment on the property.
explanation: Inspectors will seek to uncover any safety or health hazards on a property during a home inspection, as well as defects that could jeopardize a structure's integrity, such as moisture or pest intrusion.

topic: Laws of Agency and Fiduciary Duties
subtopic: Disclosure of Acting as Principal or Other Interest
question_text: Danielle is selling her home and has enlisted Camden as her agent. Shortly after signing the listing agreement, Camden informs Danielle that he'd like to purchase her home. What can Danielle do?
A: Danielle may cancel the listing agreement and seek representation from another agent.
C: Danielle must cancel the listing agreement.
D: She already signed the listing agreement with Camden. She must fulfill the contract.
explanation: The agent must put the client's interests ahead of their own, but sellers may be skeptical. Sellers may cancel the listing agreement and seek representation from another agent, but they are not obligated to do so.

topic: Contracts
question_text: A contract for an illegal purpose is ______.
explanation: Contracts must have a legal purpose. This means that a valid contract must be written for a lawful objective. A contract for an illegal purpose is therefore void.

topic: Practice of Real Estate and Disclosures, Including Specialty Areas
subtopic: Licensing and Continuing Education Requirements and Procedures
question_text: Consuela is a real estate licensee, and she has three other licensees working under her supervision. What type of license does Consuela hold?
explanation: Only the broker category of licensure gives the authority to supervise other licensees.

topic: Transfer of Property
question_text: Your client just accepted an offer from a buyer for a property in northern California. What information will NOT be provided to the escrow agent as part of the escrow instructions?
explanation: The title insurance policy hasn't yet been issued, so it's not part of the required instructions for the escrow agent. The title insurer will provide a preliminary report as an initial step of the escrow process.

topic: Practice of Real Estate and Disclosures, Including Specialty Areas
subtopic: Licensing and Continuing Education Requirements and Procedures
question_text: Edwina has a California salesperson license. Which of these statements is true?
A: She must associate with a broker in order to perform any real estate activities.
B: She must obtain a broker's license before she can perform any real estate activities.
C: She's allowed to perform a limited set of real estate activities with this license.
D: She's allowed to perform all real estate activities, and may choose to work as an individual licensee or to associate with a broker.
explanation: A licensed salesperson must be employed by a licensed broker in order to legally perform real estate activities.

topic: Practice of Real Estate and Disclosures, Including Specialty Areas
subtopic: Licensing and Continuing Education Requirements and Procedures
question_text: Which agency issues the MLO endorsement?
D: Nationwide Mortgage Licensing System and Registry (NMLS&R)
explanation: The Nationwide Mortgage Licensing System and Registry (NMLS&R) is responsible for issuing the MLO endorsement to qualified applicants who hold real estate licenses obtained through the California Department of Real Estate.

topic: Practice of Real Estate and Disclosures, Including Specialty Areas
question_text: Which of the following best describes a mixed-use property?
A: A book store with a coffee shop in it
B: A building with commercial below and residential above
D: One that melds classic design with modern design
explanation: Mixed use means two zoning categories in one building, such as commercial (often retail) mixed with residential.

topic: Transfer of Property
question_text: A family purchased a dilapidated townhome in an estate sale. Due to their fix-up work and the current economy, the property value has skyrocketed. They decide to sell it to get their equity out of it. After they list it, a woman comes forward, saying she is an heir to the previous owner and lays claim to the property. Which general warranty deed covenant protects the family?
C: The covenant of the right to convey
explanation: The covenant of warranty assures that the grantor will warrant and defend the title against the lawful claims of others.

topic: Practice of Real Estate and Disclosures, Including Specialty Areas
question_text: Which of these is an example of puffery?
A: An ad boasts that a property is "just blocks from the proposed metro light rail station."
B: An ad for a newly renovated home states, "New from the studs up." The renovation wasn't that thorough.
C: An ad for a property next to a cemetery says it "overlooks a serene, peaceful green space."
D: MLS remarks note that a condo has the city's "most beautiful twilight view of downtown and the bay."
explanation: Claiming that a property has the "most beautiful" view is the best example of puffery. The ad that mentions the light rail station includes a verifiable claim, while the ad for the renovated home is fraudulent. The ad for the property next to the cemetery is accurate even though it's in poor taste.

topic: Laws of Agency and Fiduciary Duties
question_text: Listings for sale or lease involving ______ to ______unit residential and commercial properties require agency disclosure in California.
explanation: Agency disclosure is required for listings for sale or lease involving one to four unit residential properties and non-residential (commercial) properties.

topic: Property Valuation and Financial Analysis
question_text: What service does a lender order to determine a home's actual value?
explanation: An appraisal by an unbiased appraiser will give her an estimate of the true (or fair market) value of what the home is worth.

topic: Contracts
question_text: A buyer made a partial earnest money deposit. The seller accepted the lesser deposit, and the sale was ultimately finalized. What is this an example of?
explanation: In this example, the seller accepted partial performance as a means of remedying the breach of contract.

topic: Contracts
question_text: Shannon doesn't understand why her agent wants her to add a contingency to her purchase offer. Her agent, Scott, explains that the property is in a transitional neighborhood, and it might be overpriced. What type of contingency is Scott recommending?
explanation: An appraisal contingency gives the buyer the opportunity to renegotiate the price if the appraisal comes in less than the agreed-upon purchase price. This is an important contingency in an area where values are shifting.

topic: Contracts
question_text: What type of contract is an offer to purchase a specific piece of real estate that does not obligate the offeror to buy it?
explanation: An option contract is an offer, but not an obligation, to buy a piece of real estate.

topic: Contracts
question_text: Grant owns a property that's subject to an option contract. Grant is the ______.
explanation: The property seller in an option contract is known as the optionor.

topic: Contracts
question_text: In a purchase offer, is earnest money required in order to have a binding contract?
A: No, because earnest money isn't part of a sales contract.
B: No, because the buyer's consideration is the promise to buy.
D: Yes, because it's the buyer's consideration.
explanation: Earnest money isn't required in order to have a binding sales contract (although it's usually required by the seller!). If no earnest money is provided, the prospective buyer's only consideration is the promise to pay the purchase price.

topic: Transfer of Property
question_text: Which document is used to establish proof of ownership?
explanation: The deed is used to establish proof of ownership and to as an instrument to transfer the title. Deeds should be recorded to protect the buyer from future claims of ownership.

topic: Laws of Agency and Fiduciary Duties
subtopic: Law, Definition and Nature of Agency Relationships, Types of Agencies, and Agents
question_text: Which of the following describes a universal agent?
explanation: A universal agent has broad authority to act on behalf of the principal, such as a person with a power of attorney or a conservator. A special or specific agent has limited scope of authority.

topic: Transfer of Property
question_text: At the start of the escrow process, the escrow agent delivers the ______ from the title insurance company to the buyer for review.
explanation: The preliminary report from the title insurer identifies the property, the recorded owner, and any recorded encumbrances. It's the basis for the title insurance the buyer requests.

topic: Laws of Agency and Fiduciary Duties
question_text: Which of these transactions in California is exempt from agency disclosure requirements?
D: Two-year lease of a residential unit
explanation: Agency disclosure is not required for transactions involving residential properties with five or more units, as these are exempt from this disclosure requirement.

topic: Contracts
question_text: If a party to a contract lacks legal capacity but enters into a contract anyway, which party may void the contract?
explanation: If the party doesn't have legal capacity and enters into a contract anyway, the contract is voidable by the party lacking legal capacity. So an adult can't hold a minor to a contract; however, the minor can hold the adult to the contract.

topic: Contracts
question_text: What's the best definition of legal purpose?
B: Mentally capable of entering into a contract
explanation: Legal purpose means that contracts must be written for a lawful objective. A contract for an illegal purpose is void.

topic: Transfer of Property
question_text: When you're working with clients in California, how will you explain the grant deed to them?
A: It includes implied warranties from the grantor, and is commonly used in California.
B: It includes six express covenants from the grantor, but is rarely used in California.
C: It's used in transactions where no consideration or consideration of "love and affection" is given in exchange for the property.
D: It's used to convey title when the property is used as security for a loan.
explanation: The grant deed is used to convey title in most transactions in California. It includes an implied warranty that the property is free from encumbrances.

topic: Contracts
question_text: Which of the following features is shared by the mortgage and the deed of trust?
A: In the case of foreclosure, the borrower has a statutory right of redemption.
C: The borrower is required to maintain the property and pay property taxes and insurance.
D: There are three parties involved: a lender, a borrower, and a party who holds title to the property.
explanation: Regardless of the security instrument used, it's the borrower's responsibility to maintain the property during the term of the loan.

topic: Transfer of Property
question_text: A lender asked a trustee to begin foreclosure proceedings as permitted by the power-of-sale clause in the security instrument. What type of foreclosure process is being used?
explanation: Non-judicial foreclosures do not require court involvement.

topic: Laws of Agency and Fiduciary Duties
subtopic: Responsibilities of Agent to Seller/Buyer as Principal
question_text: To whom does a licensee owe the duty of disclosure of material facts?
D: The seller or buyer, if they are customers
explanation: Disclosure of material facts is required for all parties, whether they're represented or not.

topic: Contracts
question_text: Which mortgage clause requires the lender to discharge the mortgage lien once the borrower has paid in full?
explanation: The defeasance clause means that the lender is prevented from trying to pursue additional payment because the loan has been paid in full.

topic: Property Valuation and Financial Analysis
question_text: When appraising a property, what type of property would be best suited to the cost approach?
explanation: While depreciation is difficult to appraise, the uniqueness of a historical property is likely to carry more weight than the difficulty of adjusting for depreciation.

topic: Property Valuation and Financial Analysis
question_text: Marcy's offer on a home was accepted! Which party will be contacting her about arranging an appraisal?
explanation: Lenders order appraisals before agreeing to underwrite a loan. A lender won't finance the purchase of a property used for collateral unless the underlying value meets the lender's underwriting standards.

topic: Laws of Agency and Fiduciary Duties
question_text: Sue believes she's about to get into an undisclosed dual agency position. What should she do?
A: Inform all parties to the transaction
explanation: This is important to know! Licensees must avoid getting into an undisclosed dual agency position, and should inform the parties immediately if it appears that dual agency is about to occur.

topic: Contracts
question_text: Bill and Mindy, who are neighbors, get into a disagreement about late-night noise. The two come to an agreement: Bill promises to stop having loud parties and Mindy promises to keep her dogs inside after 10 p.m. Their promises represent the ______ in their agreement.
explanation: Consideration is the giving of something of value in exchange for something of value. This isn't always monetary value, as this exchange of promises demonstrates.

topic: Property Valuation and Financial Analysis
question_text: Which economic principle is related to supply and demand?
explanation: Competition impacts value because the more similar properties that are on the market, the lower the price will be driven. Competition is related to supply and demand.

topic: Property Valuation and Financial Analysis
question_text: What's the capitalization formula used in the income approach?
D: Value = net operating income  cap rate
explanation: The basic capitalization formula used in the income approach has three parts: value, capitalization (cap) rate, and net operating income. The formula is value = net operating income  cap rate.

topic: Contracts
question_text: When offer and acceptance has occurred, both parties enter into ______.
explanation: If an offer and acceptance has been made, it means the parties have entered into a mutual agreement.

topic: Laws of Agency and Fiduciary Duties
question_text: Which one of the following actions would result in the legal termination of an agency agreement?
A: The client wants the seller to make improvements to the property.
B: The client wants to attach an addendum to the sales contract.
C: There's an unexpected death in the agent's family.
D: The term specified in the agency agreement expired.
explanation: If the specified term in the agency agreement expires, the agency agreement would be terminated.

topic: Property Valuation and Financial Analysis
question_text: Which of these principles of value is related to how a change to a portion of a property impacts the value as a whole?
explanation: The principle of contribution says that a change to a portion of a property impacts the overall value. For example, adding a swimming pool could add to the value for some buyers and detract from the value for others.

topic: Contracts
question_text: What is an open listing agreement?
A: One in which anyone can find the buyer, but the listing agent still gets paid
B: One in which only the person who finds the buyer gets paid
C: One in which the price is negotiable within a specified range
D: One in which there's no end date
explanation: In an open listing agreement, only the licensee who locates the buyer will be paid. If the seller locates the buyer, no compensation is owed.

topic: Property Valuation and Financial Analysis
question_text: Which of the following is the cost of replacing a building in the case of total loss?
explanation: Insured value should be the cost of replacement in the event the property's destroyed.

topic: Laws of Agency and Fiduciary Duties
question_text: When the listing agreement's purpose has been fulfilled, what happens to the agency agreement?
B: Agency continues until the agreement's expiration date.
C: The agency agreement terminates by completion.
D: The agent can renounce the listing agreement to terminate it.
explanation: Agency terminates when the goal of the agreement is completed. The duty of accounting remains until finished, and the duty of confidentiality remains forever.

topic: Property Valuation and Financial Analysis
question_text: Which of these is what a buyer has paid for a property and what the seller has accepted?
explanation: Price is the actual amount that a buyer pays for a property. It may be the same as the market value, or it may not.

topic: Property Valuation and Financial Analysis
question_text: What "quick and dirty" investment formula seeks to achieve a percentage of gross monthly rental income as compared to purchase price?
explanation: There is a formula called the 2% formula that states that the gross monthly rental income should be at least 2% of the purchase price.

topic: Financing
question_text: Which of the following describes amortization?
A: A decrease in a property's value
B: An increase in a property's value
D: Paying off a loan over time
explanation: Amortization is the paying off of a loan over time.

topic: Financing
question_text: In which market do lenders that originate real estate loans operate?
explanation: The primary mortgage market is where loans are made to consumers before they're bundled and sold on the secondary market.

topic: Financing
question_text: Which of these is a type of gap financing that's used temporarily until the consumer can obtain permanent financing?
explanation: A bridge loan is a temporary (usually 90-day) loan that provides funds in addition to an existing loan until permanent financing can be obtained. It's often used by buyers who've not yet sold their prior property.

topic: Financing
question_text: Which of the following entities generally acts in the secondary market?
explanation: Traditional secondary market players are national institutions, such as Fannie Mae, Freddie Mac, Ginnie Mae, and the Federal Home Loan Bank.

topic: Practice of Real Estate and Disclosures, Including Specialty Areas
question_text: Which type of antitrust violation occurs when providing one service is made dependent on the customer or client obtaining another recommended service?
explanation: Tie-in arrangements are antitrust violations that involve predicating one service on the consumer purchasing another from a recommended company. These arrangements severely limit choices for consumers.

topic: Practice of Real Estate and Disclosures, Including Specialty Areas
question_text: What is the MLS?
A: A database of real estate information
B: A list of buyers and their contact information
C: A server that records incoming data in a mirror image
D: Photo editing software for real estate licensees
explanation: The MLS is a shared database of real estate information, including properties for sale and recent sales, as well as pending, expired, and withdrawn listings.

topic: Property Ownership and Land Use Controls and Regulations
question_text: Which amendment to CERCLA says that "innocent landowners" aren't responsible for the cleanup of hazardous contamination?
explanation: The Superfund Amendments and Reauthorization Act, or SARA, says that innocent landowners aren't responsible for cleanup of hazardous contamination.

topic: Practice of Real Estate and Disclosures, Including Specialty Areas
question_text: The purpose of ______ is to balance the trust account and ensure that all funds deposited or disbursed are properly recorded.
explanation: This statement describes trust fund reconciliation, which should be performed at least monthly.

topic: Practice of Real Estate and Disclosures, Including Specialty Areas
question_text: What organization's mission is to promote democracy in housing?
A: Asian Real Estate Association of America (AREAA)
B: Minority Real Estate Professionals of America (MREPA)
C: National Association of Hispanic Real Estate Professionals (NAHREP)
D: National Association of Real Estate Brokers (NAREB)
explanation: NAREB has a mission of "promoting democracy in housing."

topic: Property Valuation and Financial Analysis
question_text: Althea is starting her own candle business. Her plan is to rent a space to sell her products for several years, with the hope of expanding. In this scenario, which item represents supply?
explanation: Business owners are looking for commercial spaces. In this scenario, the space available for lease represents the supply Althea will consider.

topic: Property Valuation and Financial Analysis
question_text: What do appraisers use in addition to depreciation to determine the indicated value when using the cost approach?
explanation: The cost approach determines the indicated value by estimating the reproduction cost of the new improvement and subtracting the amount of depreciation. Then, the appraiser adds an estimate of the site value as if it were vacant and available to be developed to its highest and best use.

topic: Property Valuation and Financial Analysis
question_text: What is before-tax cash flow?
A: Cash flow after property taxes are considered.
B: Cash flow before property taxes are considered.
C: Cash flow before taking income taxes into account.
D: Cash flow taking income taxes into account.
explanation: The taxes in question are income taxes, and not property taxes. Before-tax cash flow is income without considering taxes.

topic: Laws of Agency and Fiduciary Duties
subtopic: Disclosure of Acting as Principal or Other Interest
question_text: Which of the following is a true statement about buying one's own listing?
A: Even when it's legal, some brokerages won't allow their agents to do it.
B: If full disclosure is provided to the seller, it is fine to do.
D: It's a great way to make money in real estate.
explanation: Full disclosure and brokerage permission are required. Even so, licensees should proceed carefully to avoid a charge of misrepresentation.

topic: Property Valuation and Financial Analysis
question_text: If there is some kind of defect on a property's title, what effect does this level of transferability have on the property's value?
D: Transferability has no effect on value.
explanation: If a property can't be easily transferred, its value falls.

topic: Laws of Agency and Fiduciary Duties
question_text: Which of the following lease agreements should be accompanied by an agency disclosure?
explanation: Agency disclosure is required for leases exceeding one year.

topic: Laws of Agency and Fiduciary Duties
subtopic: Law, Definition and Nature of Agency Relationships, Types of Agencies, and Agents
question_text: Rhonda is an unrepresented buyer who's purchasing Tony's townhome. Gary represents Tony in the sale of his property. What's Rhonda's relationship to Gary?
explanation: Rhonda is Gary's customer. She's not his client because no agency relationship exists between them.

topic: Laws of Agency and Fiduciary Duties
question_text: Which of the following situations would require agency disclosure?
A: A prospective buyer asks a licensee whether appliances are ENERGY STAR
B: A prospective buyer asks a listing agent the price of the property
C: A prospective buyer asks an agent their license status
D: A prospective buyer asks an agent why the sellers are moving
explanation: This goes to motivation and is in the realm of confidential information; it requires agency disclosure.

topic: Laws of Agency and Fiduciary Duties
question_text: A seller decides to terminate her listing agreement and rent the property out instead of selling it after it's been on the market for several months with no offers. Assuming that her listing agent has fulfilled all of his responsibilities under the contract, can the seller terminate the contract before its expiration date?
A: Only if the seller and the listing agent mutually agree to terminate the agreement.
B: Only if the seller succeeds in converting it to a rental.
C: Yes, because the seller has not received any offers on the listing.
D: Yes, because the seller is entitled to terminate the agreement at any time.
explanation: Since the listing agent hasn't done anything to breach the contract, the seller's only options are to let the listing agreement expire or try to reach mutual agreement with the listing agent to terminate the agreement without penalty.

topic: Laws of Agency and Fiduciary Duties
question_text: Which of the following statements best describes a listing that terminates by performance?
A: Evan performed all required fiduciary duties and tasks in listing Von's house, even though it didn't sell before the listing expired.
B: Greg listed a property that failed to sell during the term of the listing agreement. Aside from that, he performed all the tasks promised to the seller.
C: Marty listed Todd's condo. With Marty's efforts they got almost to closing only to have the buyer's financing fall through.
D: Roberto listed a property for Terrence. After two failed offers, the property made it to a successful closing.
explanation: No matter how well a licensee performs his tasks, a listing agreement is terminated by completion /performance only if it successfully closes.

topic: Laws of Agency and Fiduciary Duties
question_text: Under what circumstances would undisclosed dual agency be most likely to occur?
A: When meeting a buyer at an open house
B: When meeting a seller at an open house
C: When representing a seller and assisting an unrepresented buyer
D: When representing the buyer and assisting a seller who is represented by another broker
explanation: Because an agency agreement is already in place with the seller (the listing agreement), assisting the buyer too much can lead to undisclosed dual agency.

topic: Laws of Agency and Fiduciary Duties
question_text: Bradley provided his clients with a dual agency disclosure. He obtained his clients' signatures and provided copies to his clients. What step did he miss?
A: He did not make sure his clients understood the form before signing it.
B: He did not offer to also mail his clients a certified copy.
C: He did not receive his broker's permission.
D: No steps; if he obtained signatures, he has done his job.
explanation: Actually, obtaining signatures is not enough. Licensees must first make certain that clients understand what they are giving up in a dual agency situation before they sign the form.

topic: Property Valuation and Financial Analysis
question_text: What guidelines must an appraiser follow?
D: Uniform Standards of Professional Appraisal Practice (USPAP)
explanation: The Uniform Standards of Professional Appraisal Practice provides standards for appraisers to follow.
